item.title: Independent game festival Freeplay warns its days could be numbered
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 20, 2026

2 Min Read

Australian independent video game festival, Freeplay, could be forced to wind down after struggling to secure funding. 

In a lengthy post on the Freeplay website, festival organizers said recent attempts to secure financing were unsuccessful and claimed other relevant funding opportunities are nonexistent. 

It's a situation that could result in Freeplay, which bills itself as the longest-running independent game festival in the world, ceasing operations. 

"Last year, Freeplay applied to Creative Victoria's Creative Enterprises fund. Unfortunately, our application was unsuccessful. This means we do not currently have ongoing funding to support our organization, and there are no relevant and available opportunities for Freeplay on the horizon," reads the post. 

"As such, we are unable to continue paying our co-directors a salary to run Freeplay events, and there is no guarantee we can operate beyond 2026. 

We are currently operating with our volunteer board steering the ship whilst we arrange plans for our slated events this year. Based on the resources we currently have, Freeplay is likely looking at its last year of operation for the foreseeable future." 

Freeplay organizers claim video games are no longer being prioritized by local government 

Related:Former Assassin's Creed boss sues Ubisoft over alleged 'disguised dismissal'

Festival organizers claimed Freeplay's failure to secure funding via Creative Victoria (which is backed by the local government) is indicative of a shift away from video games. 

"We’re disappointed in the outcome and what it implies about how games are currently being prioritised by the Victorian Government," they added. "Of the 81 arts organizations supported by Creative Enterprises in the 2026-2029 funding round, none are games/interactive arts organizations." 

Creative Victoria previously awarded Freeplay two years of organization funding in 2023. That covered the day-to-day costs of running the festival and the hiring of two part-time co-directors. 

Now, with the festival at a crossroads, organizers have turned to the Freeplay community for advice on how to chart a path forward. 

"We are at a crossroads, considering what this means for Freeplay’s future. Freeplay has been a cornerstone of the Australian games community for over 20 years, and if its time is up, we refuse to let it disappear without a bang," the post continues.

"[...] To help us decide the best path forward, we would love input from the community. We want to ensure we’re using our remaining resources to deliver events and programs that contribute meaningfully to Australia’s artistic and experimental gamemaking community."
